column13: Harden's the clear number 1 option if he stays in Houston and he's motivated, but right now his motivation is being questioned. I won't blame you for taking somebody else with the number 1 pick
If LeBron misses time early it'll be the Anthony Davis show in LA. Has an elite fantasy game and an ever improving 3-point shot
An elite fantasy player who managed to up his three-pointers made from 1.8 to 3.3 per-game without hurting his FG%. Should be happier on the court with his close friend D'Angelo Russell on the roster
Steph is a career 47.6% shooter from the field, so the 40.2% from last season (5 game sample size) was an outlier
Continues to return top-5 value, but is often not taken until the end of the first round
An elite per-game fantasy player. His on-going knee issues might be an issue in a compacted fantasy schedule, but he'll still be a top-8 fantasy player
Skinny Jokic is a baller, but cevapi remains undefeated, so we'll see how he looks coming into next season. Still a top-10 player in any format, regardless of weight
The addition of Capela means more assists. Expect another strong season as Young continues to develop into a fantasy first-round staple

Went from being a liability in both shooting %s in his rookie season to shooting 46.3% from FG% and 75.8% from FT% in his second season. If he can edge his FT% up a little he'll be an early to mid-first-round guy for seasons to come.
His game keeps on getting better every season. Finished 12th in per-game value last season so if you can get him in the second-round then you've got yourself a steal
He's a top fantasy player when he's switched on. Target him in a trade when he has a stretch of lower than expected output. Still a top-15 guy
The talent is always going to be there, it's just a matter of whether he can stay on the court.
His FT% almost dipped down to his FG% last season, but if you're drafting Giannis you're punting FT%, and he's the best fantasy player in punt FT% builds
His value is running low after a lackluster playoff performance. A much better performer during the regular season, which is what counts for fantasy basketball
Has the potential to be a top-25 player this season if he can up his output in any of his negative value categories (3PM, AST, or STL)
LeBron Rule 101: Don't write him off as an elite fantasy player until his body actually breaks down. Might miss games early as LA prepares for another championship run

Butler seems to be in a happy place with the hard-working Heat. He seems more willing to share the workload, which doesn't bode well for fantasy output. Still, somebody to target at the end of the second round
Improved his scoring from 15,7 to 23.4, and if his playoff run was anything to go by he's due for another small increase as he becomes the focus on the offensive end.
The Bam break-out happened last season. Expect the offense to continue running through his hands as he establishes himself as a top-30 fantasy player

His FG% will always be an issue since almost half of his field-goal attempts are from behind the arc, but he makes up for it with his elite shot-blocking. Injuries are the only thing limiting his upside
Will be better for the run during the resumption of the NBA season, and the starting job in Portland is his, so long as he's healthy. Should be back to 2018-19 Nurkic this season
If players are forced to play a compact schedule then you can expect Brooklyn to be a little cautious with Durant
His membership has been revoked from the 1-1-1 club (averaging 1 3-pointer, 1 steal, and 1 block), but he's working on getting it back
Shot 3% above his second-best FG% season, so it's questionable whether he'll be able to sustain shooting at 49.7% from the field, but he has an uber-friendly fantasy game even if he doesn't
Westbrook getting traded to Washington is going to impact Beal's usage, so expect dips across the board in points, rebounds, and assists
Capela and Gallinari will impact his output, but he's got great shooting %s, which will keep his value high as his counting stats take a dip from last season
It's debatable whether LaVine is a good-stats-bad-team guy, but you can't deny the numbers he's putting up and should continue to flirt with top 30-40 value this season.
Sometimes players have the reputation of being such a good defender, that teams shoot less around them, and that's what's happening to Gobert. He's still an elite shot-blocker

Westbrook's shooting percentages are looking good now that he's attempting fewer 3-pointers and attacking the rim more. Expect his assists to bounce up a little without having to share the ball as much with Beal as he did with Harden
An elite fantasy player in punt FT% builds, but it's hard to see him become a top-20 fantasy player until he starts to work on developing his outside game
Had one of the best fantasy seasons of his career, and played a career-high in minutes. All at the age of 34
The history of small, 35-year-old point guards isn't on his side, but you can't deny the season he just had in OKC
He has managed to improve his fantasy output while maintaining his solid shooting percentages. Will be a quality fantasy option for years to come
NBA Finals Fred has evolved into Regular Season VanVleet, and he's a fantasy stud. He'll continue to play a key role in Toronto moving forward
Has a great playoff performance and should continue to improve his fantasy output this season, but his lack of defensive numbers limit his ability to return top-25 value
Still manages to be a top-50 fantasy producer even though he refuses to attempt three-point shots
He's back in Cleveland this season, which is one of the few teams he's still able to produce top fantasy numbers on
Didn't handle the pressure of playoff basketball too well, but he had an off-season to work on it, and won't face the same pressure during the regular season
It feels like his playoff bubble performance is going to inflate his value a little too much heading into fantasy drafts
As consistent as they come, and still has another season of high-level play in him, whether it's in San Antonio or another on another roster
He's clearly the best big-man on the roster, and his game meshes extremely well with the other starters in Indiana. Expect his high output to continue into this season
Is in a happier scenario in Minnesota, but there's a chance some of his usage gets eaten into with the player who comes in with the number 1 pick
Brook has found a way to extend his career as a 3-point sniper who's capable of hitting 2+ threes and getting 2+ blocks a game
Has proven that he's more than capable of continuing to stuff the stat sheet alongside a healthy Zion
His output has been inconsistent to date, so expect some quiet games, but his upside is huge. May not reach it this season, but I'm expecting improvements from JJJ heading into his third season
Westbrook being traded opens up the opportunity for Wood to play a bigger role in Houston's offense
The move to PF did wonders for his already excellent fantasy game (REB went up to 8 and BLK went up to 2.2 per game in a 22 game regular season sample size in Houston)

His good categories are good (48% from the field, 21.1 PTS, 1.5 STL last season), but his bad ones are bad (70.5% from the line). If he can improve on his consistency then he's a chance to break into the top-50

He's not a strong rebounder, and playing next to Sabonis isn't going to help that, but what he does provide is elite shot-blocking, the ability to hit 3s, and not hurt you too much from the free-throw line
Had a great rookie season. My only concern is with how ferocious he attacks the rim, given his slender frame. Capable of averaged 20 PTS and 8 AST heading into his second season
He's back to playing at an elite level and has minimal competition at either of the guard spots in Milwaukee
Put up top-100 value playing 22 minutes a game last season and is set for his role to increase. Has a fantasy-friendly game with elite FG%
Finished 52nd in per-game value last season, but Memphis has JJJ and Clarke capable of playing minutes at C. Should still return top 80-90 value this season
At this point, we need to stop looking at Sexton as a PG. He's a score-first combo-guard, who still has potential to improve his assist numbers. He hasn't shown it yet, though

Goes from cold-shooting stretches to hitting everything as frequently as any player I've seen in the league (last season there were 3 individual months where he shot 48%+ from the field and 3 individual months where he shot 44% or lower).
Continues to be a roto-friendly player who won't hurt you in any categories
His reputation exceeds his output, but when he's producing he's capable of being a top-75 fantasy player
Almost doubled his PTS from last season and increased his output across the board

His production started to pick up towards the end of last season, but he's still limited as a fantasy player until he improves his scoring. Can still be a top-80 player without needing to score more than 10 PPG
When he plays, he plays well, but it becomes a little harder to trust his health with every new injury
I feel like his bubble performance has inflated his value, but his plantar fasciitis injury could see him miss time early in the season

His lack of defensive effort is starting to become noticeable, but it would be a hard task for anybody asked to be the defensive anchor on this roster. Best suited as a second-unit big man who feasts on weaker lineups, but is more than capable of being a long-term starter
Looks like playing with Zion has had a positive impact on his fantasy output, but his shooting %s continue to be horrible and he'll slide in drafts given his play in the bubble
There's still a little more growth left in his game, but he needs to up his steal rate to take his fantasy game to the next level
Was putting up elite numbers before Oladipo returned and then settled into a top-100 guy, which is where you can expect his output to hover around this season
The Mitchell Robinson rollercoaster is set to continue for another season. The potential is there, but he needs to get better on the defensive end (and stop biting at every shot attempt)
Has a chance to revive his career in OKC and should play a role as secondary ball facilitator in the starting line-up
Took a little longer to step-up his game, but he finally got there. Should be flirting with top-80 production if he continues to see 25+ minutes a game
A roto-friendly big man who can get you clean shooting percentages. Didn't play well under Boylen, but a better coach should be able to get more out of him
Injuries and missed games continue to hurt Lauri's fantasy value. He could slide in drafts if people are only looking at his numbers from last season
Everybody's per-minute darling finally scored himself a starting role last season, but he won't be returning top 50 value again with Whiteside fighting him for minutes at C
I like what Mikal provides long-term as a 3&D specialist, and his offensive production has started trending in the right direction
Has a chance to revive his career on the fast-paced Pelicans roster
Missed games will continue to be an issue for Love heading into the season as he finds himself playing next to somebody who has a tendancy of stealing rebounds from teammates
Atlanta has suddenly become very deep at the big man spot
We're starting to see flashes of what he's capable of, and those flashes are of a top fantasy prospect. We may not see it this season, but the potential to be elite is there
He can score, and he's doing that in Utah, but all of his value is tied to 3 categores (PTS, 3PM, FT%)

Is in a weird situation in Indiana, and may find himself on a new roster to start this season. He's a few seasons out from his one elite fantasy season and it's doubtful he'll be able to replicate his 2017-18 numbers
A solid end-of-roster guy who will put up decent numbers so long as he continues to start
Will be motivated to bounce back from a forgettable season last year, but he'll still be a negative contributor in all 3 shooting categories (FG%, FT%, PTS)
Had a good enough bubble performance that suggests minutes will open up for Bazley to start at PF
We've seen this movie before. He often starts the season slowly, then, when the season is lost he goes on a tear to finish the season
A 4-category player who's best suited to punt FG% builds
Deserves to play more minutes than he does and will again be sharing minutes at C with Jordan
Whiteside is coming back from having a very Whiteside season (putting up elite rebounds, blocks, and FG%), but he'll likely be splitting minutes at C in Sacramento
Will start the season slow given his return from injury, but I don't see his role changing much in Houston given he was always going to be playing second fiddle in Washington
Injuries will always be a concern, but Denver's best chance to jump to the next level is with MPJ improving and becoming a quality starter, so the opportunity is there so long as his body holds up
His value increases dramatically in a punt FG% build
It's not as good as OKC, but I still like the fit in Golden State
An elite shooter who doesn't provide anything outside of the scoring and shooting categories
It was a season to forget for Conley, but his performance in the playoffs suggests he's going to bounce back
Had a down season in Philly, but we know he's capable of more. I like the move to Dallas and he's somebody to target late in drafts
The steals are playing time are available in Detroit, but his value tends to hover around the end-of-roster territory
Should be available late in fantasy drafts and is a stable source of production in PTS and 3PM
Has the potential to be a top-100 staple as he continues to develop his game, mostly because of his defensive numbers
Added a three-point shot to his game, which will help extend his career. Should be returning top-100 value in LA
It looks like the starting spot at C could be in play, but even if it is, it'll still be a minutes split between Noel and Robinson
A good streaming option, but not somebody to rely on
Will Derrick Rose continue to shoot 49% from the field this season? Probably not, but he provides great value for somebody who can be had late in drafts

Didn't live up to most people's expectations last season, and his scoring is trending in the wrong direction, but he's still a good fantasy player in punt FT% builds and you won't have to draft him early
Will provide much-needed outside shooting for New Orleans this season, but at this point in his career, he doesn't offer much outside of 3PM, PTS, and FT%
Is a walking bucket, but his fantasy production is tied to 4 categories and doesn't provide any defensive stats
The transition to a starting role we've all been waiting for looks likely to happen in Detroit
He's still a little raw, but he's the best young player on the roster, so he'll continue to see minutes
Otto's value is at an all-time low after a horrible 2019-20 season. Has proven to be a stable fantasy player in prior seasons and could provide value on draft day
If we're starting with a clean slate and treated last season as his rookie season, then he's off to a good start, and he has shown signs of becoming a good rotation player
Potentially moves to the bench and is a chance to get traded given how crowded Charlotte is at the guard spot
Has a nice overall game without being a standout in any category. Should continues to increase his output heading into season two
Don't mind me, I'm just here waiting for Aaron Gordon to remember how to play basketball again

Started the season red hot, but started to slow down once teams focused on him as Charlotte's best offensive weapon. Won't get as much attention this season with Hayward on the roster, but his production is expected to dip with such a crowded guard rotation
Will be splitting minutes with Allen this season, but should still be able to produce respectable rebounding numbers if you're desperate for them
Has a well-rounded fantasy game and should be locked in as a starter for Atlanta
Is capable of being a top 100 player, but his minutes are capped with Ibaka's ability to play C
Flirted with top-80 value last season, mostly because of his 3.7 three-pointers made per game. His ceiling is capped until he starts contributing to non-shooting categories
Thibs has a habit of playing guys he likes heavy minutes, but the fit with Toppin isn't ideal for him
There's plenty of room for improvement, but he has the opportunity to cement himself as a 22-24 minute per game starter

We're starting to see a concerning pattern with Bagley. He gets hurt, comes back and does some nice things, and then misses more games. He has the potential to be a walking double-double, but he needs to find a way to stay on the court
Capable of giving you a quality return in PTS and FT%, but Atlanta isn't a great fit. He's not mobile enough to play SF full time, and Atlanta already has a quality starting PF
Landed in the absolute best spot in terms of fantasy production, and should be the opening night starter on a team starting their re-build
A stop-gap until Bagley works things out, but he has value in the short-term as a streaming option
Might get the gentleman's start at C, but I can't see him playing enough minutes to crack the top-100

His value is at an all-time low, and it's questionable how his body will hold up this season, but he's still capable of putting up numbers without relying on athletisism (averated 2.5 3PM in 2018-19 and 1.5 last season)
He's the perfect PG for this Clippers roster, but at this point in his career, he doesn't have much upside in fantasy
He's proving to be a good end-of-roster 3s and steals guy, but he doesn't do enough in other categories
Should be playing 30+ minutes a night heading into season two, but chances are he'll be over-drafted due to his playoff run
Not much long-term appeal here as he's clearly in the twilight of his career
He's a 3-point streamer when his shot is falling
Cousins will have to prove he's healthy before we can consider him a viable fantasy option this season
Coby White's game is the definition of a rollercoaster ride, but it's one you want to be taking in punt FG% builds
Can put up numbers when spot-starting, but hasn't shown any indication of being anything more than a high energy guy off the bench
He ended his season in Minnesota on a tear, but rotations are getting crowded in Minnesota
A gunner off the bench, but he provides very little in terms of non-scoring categories
We've seen this movie before. He's still capable of getting hot, but Denver are better off moving him to a bench role
A great steals and assists option who can be had late in drafts
Looked the best of the Cleveland rookies last season and had a promising stretch of games before getting injured, but Okoro limits his time at SF
He's older than most people think, but he's somebody to stream in when you need blocks
Doesn't provide anything outside of the typical big-man stats and Gasol limits his ability to play big minutes at C
At this point in his career, on this roster, he's nothing more than a blocks streamer or end-of-roster big man
Has the size and shooting ability to play SG and is an excellent fit next to Fox
I won't be surprised if we see a lot of 3-guard line-ups in Charlotte, but Hayward takes the ball out of his hands, and LaMelo is at his best when he's handling the ball
We should see the same amount of minutes from Seth this season whether it's as a fringe starter or gunner off the bench, but he's not much more than a 3PM streamer or end-of-bench guy
The starting spot should be his and the Raptors inherit the best fan account on Twitter
Potentially comes off the bench next season and the addition of Hayward limits his ability to break out
He hasn't had a great start to his career but should improve heading into season two (even if his FG% doesn't)
Wiggins is Golden States' problem now, but I have more faith in him playing within an offense for the Warriors than any other roster
The lone center on the roster (who's really a SF/PF) is expected to play as many minutes as his body can handle. Still, only a borderline top-100 guy even if he's playing 35 minutes a night

The often injured Zeller is younger than you think, and when he's fit and firing he provides end of the roster value, but that's not often enough (hasn't played more than 62 games since his rookie season in 2013-14).
Expecting him to split minutes at C with his minutes gradually increasing as the season goes on
Has apparently won the starting spot in Portland, but don't expect him to put up big numbers
His output will increase when Porzingis is out of the lineup, but he's not somebody to rely on
Harris will get plenty of open looks as teams focus their defensive efforts on Kyrie and KD
His fantasy output has started to regress, but the assists and 3-pointers should still be there
His ceiling is capped, and it doesn't look like he'll be more than a contributor to the PTS, 3PM, and FT% categories
His ceiling is being able to spot-start as a low usage defensive specialist
Doesn't provide much outside of points and 3s and has little upside moving forward. There are more exciting picks to make
Is capable of putting up numbers when given the opportunity to play, but he's not somebody a team is willing to start long-term so his minutes will always be capped
Has yet to prove that he's anything more than a blocks specialist at this early stage of his career
Wouldn't be surprised if he's traded again before the season officially starts
It's time to accept Harris for what he is - a decent real-life NBA player, but a below-average fantasy player.
Had a dramatic increase in output last season, but his usage won't be as high in LA
Don't expect bubble Dragic to return this season
A defensive stud, but he needs to develop a three-point shot to keep himself on the court
Didn't really take the opportunity on a depleted Washington roster last season, but still has some untapped potential
Dinwiddie's output this season is tied to whether he remains on the Nets roster. If he stays in Brooklyn then he'll still be productive, but he won't be putting up top-80 value.
Didn't have the best on-court (and off-court) bubble experience and he's not somebody to rely on in standard leagues
He's behind quite a few players on the depth chart in San Antonio, so his opportunity is limited in the short-term, but he has the potential to be a good 2-way player
In a position battle for the back-up C spot, which doesn't bode well for his fantasy output
His shooting percentages improved from his rookie season and should continue to develop. His upside seems limited, though
His streaky shooting means he's best suited to punt FG% builds
One of the better shooters on the Detroit roster, but he needs to add more elements to his game to be fantasy relevant
A 3-point streamer who's still capable of getting close to a steal and block a game, but he's not somebody to look at unless you're in a deep league
Is currently showing signs of being a capable rotation player when given the minutes
If Baynes signs with another team the role of a back-up stretch-5 is his
More of an end-of-roster kind of guy who's capable of putting up stable numbers when filling in for an injured player
Moves to a bench role in Utah
His athletic ability allows him to get to the rim, and when he's not driving he's taking 3s (and sometimes too deep), but he tends to go missing during play and shot a poor % in college
I wouldn't be shocked to see Caris on a new team at some point next season as the fit with a Kyrie and KD led Brooklyn Nets roster isn't a great one
Is developing a nice all-around fantasy game, but his FG% will hurt you
Has just scored himself a new 3-year contract, which means he's definitely in Memphis' long-term plans, but his game doesn't translate well to fantasy
His upside is capped on the talented Philly roster, but he should see minutes as a spot-started as they continue to tinker with their lineup
Best case scenario Frank becomes a Marcus Smart type player, worst case scenario he remains a Knick for the rest of his career
Seems set to continue playing 20 minutes as a backup
Kanter relies on specific match-ups to get minutes
Showed enough last season to earn himself a spot in the rotation as a back-up stretch-4
At best, he's an end of your fantasy roster kind of guy

Let's hope RJ is currently in a gym working on his shooting, because if he can somehow become a respectable shooter, then he's a chance to be a good fantasy player. Until then, he's better suited to points-leagues
Has failed to build on his promising rookie season and it looks like his upside is capped as a bench player
Should split minutes at C with Theis, but he needs big minutes to be fantasy relevant
Might have some value if he spot-starts since Kemba tends to miss games

He finds himself in a situation where he plays the same position as an important piece of his new team (again), but this time that piece is the often injured Marvin Bagley. Could have some value in the short-term when Bagley is hurt (which happens often)

I was hoping Okongwu landed to a team looking for a starting big-man, but, he, unfortunately, fell to a team with John Collins and Clint Capela. It might be a season or two before he gets the opportunity to play big minutes
Lauri Markkanen is often injured, so Young still has short-term value as a spot-starter
The fit with Randle isn't great, but you have to assume they drafted Toppin for a reason, and that's to score
A streamer when he spot-starts, otherwise he's somebody to avoid
